Towards conversion of octanoic acid to liquid hydrocarbon via hydrodeoxygenation over Mo promoter nickel-based catalyst Yanan Duan a b Yulong Wu b ⁎ Qinhui Zhang a Ranran Ding b Yu Chen b Ji Liu b Mingde Yang b a College of Chemical Engineering, China University of Petroleum, Shandong 266580, PR China College of Chemical Engineering China University of Petroleum Shandong 266580 PR China b Institute of Nuclear and New Energy Technology, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084, PR China Institute of Nuclear and New Energy Technology Tsinghua University Beijing 100084 PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +86 10 89796086; fax: +86 10 69771464. Graphical abstract When no Mo content was present, the major product of octanoic acid conversion was C7. Adding certain Mo particles to the Ni–ZrO2 catalyst could not only improve the octanoic acid conversion but was also beneficial to the generation of C8 alkane distinctly. Meanwhile, the selectivity of C8 had an increasing trend with the Mo content till 10wt%, at which the C8 selectivity reached to its maximum of 77.07% with a complete acid conversion. When the Mo content increased to 15wt%, the octanoic acid conversion as well as C8 selectivity decreased sharply. This could be attributed to that an excess of Mo particles would cover the Ni active sites as well as anionic vacancies on the surface of ZrO2 support. The different product distributions suggested different octanoic acid conversion mechanisms prevailed over the Ni–ZrO2 and Mo/Ni–ZrO2 catalysts. In the current paper, Mo doped Ni–ZrO2 catalyst was prepared, which was used for the liquid hydrocarbon from conversion of octanoic acid via hydrodeoxygenation (HDO). The experimental results showed that the reaction product is mainly C8 alkane with a yield of 77.07% when 10Mo/Ni–ZrO2 was used as the catalyst compared with the major product of C7 alkane over Ni–ZrO2 catalyst with a yield of 69.68%. The introduction of Mo into the Ni–ZrO2 channel generated in Mo/Ni–ZrO2 samples was characterized by nitrogen sorption, TEM, XRD, TPR, and TPD. The results demonstrated that the doping Mo particles to the Ni–ZrO2 catalyst resulted in the transformation of ZrO2 support from cubic form (c-ZrO2) to monoclinic form (m-ZrO2), and the improvement of the hydrogen adsorption capacity and acid property of the catalyst. Thus, the doping of Mo favored the dehydration–hydrogenation reactions of octanol intermediate which in turn facilitated octanoic acid HDO to C8 alkane. Therefore, a novel approach to octanoic acid HDO to C8 alkane is introduced, which provides a basis as well as technical parameters for its further industrialization. Keywords Octanoic acid HDO Nickel-based catalyst Liquid hydrocarbon Mo promoter 1 Introduction The increasing depletion of traditional fossil fuels, the environmental pollution caused by the use of fossil fuels, and the increased dependence upon oil imported from politically unstable parts of the world enable researchers to seek renewable, sustainable, and environmental friendly sources of energy [1]. Of those alternatives, bio-oils produced from biomass resources, which is regarded as an alternative strategy for petroleum, has now been realized, not only can help nations pursue energy independence but also mitigate the impact of human activities on environment, such as reducing greenhouse gas emission [2,3]. The bio-oils derived from biomass are promising alternative renewable liquid fuel. Moreover, the biomass-derived bio-oil has a higher energy density than that of the biomass feedstock. However, the bio-oil cannot be used directly as a liquid transportation fuel due to its high viscosity and its significant quantities of nitrogen, oxygen, and sulphur. Especially, the bio-oils from biomass contain high content of oxygen, up to 35–40wt%, which is much higher than that of petroleum. The bio-oils with high oxygen contents are complex mixtures of numerous compounds with lower vapor pressure, lower HHV, higher water solubility, and higher reactivity [4]. The ultimate aim of upgrading is to improve the quality of bio-oil by decreasing the fraction of organic acids, aldehydes, and other reactive compounds because they increase the corrosiveness and acidity. So far, the upgrading of bio-oil is a complex reaction network; representive reactions include cracking [5], decarbonylation, decarboxylation (DCO) [6], and hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) [7,8]. Among which, HDO is considered as one of the most effective methods. Compared to DCO, the HDO process of fatty acid exhibits more atom economy and eliminates oxygen by producing H2O instead of CO2, rendering it more environmentally friendly than DCO, and attracts more attentions [9]. Fatty acids, which are the main products in the bio-oil, contribute to the oxygen content and corrosiveness of the bio-oil. Therefore, the conversion of fatty acid via HDO has gained much attention. At present, long carbon chain (C16–C22) fatty acids were usually selected as model compounds for investigating the HDO reaction [10], which could be used as a substitute or additive to the conventional diesel oil after upgrading. However, published works involving the HDO conversion of medium chain length (C6–C12) aliphatic carboxylic acids which exist extensively in vegetable oils are little available, and the products obtained from the conversion can be used as transportation fuel replacing gasoline [11]. To our best knowledge, the physical properties of fatty acids with different carbon chain lengths are different, such as acidity, polarity and steric hindrance, etc. These different physical properties may lead to diverse catalytic performance over the same catalyst. So, it is necessary to study the HDO of the medium chain length fatty acid, such as octanoic acid. As a classic reaction, the product of HDO process markedly depends on the catalytic selectivity of the catalyst. Recently, there are three main catalytic systems used for the HDO of organic acid [12,13]: (1) CoMo or NiMo sulfide/supported catalysts; (2) Pd- or Pt-based supported catalysts; and (3) the supported inexpensive transition metal catalysts. However, due to the sulfur leaching and higher price of noble metal, the former two catalytic systems were restricted in the practical usage. Concerning on the high catalytic activity and lower cost in the hydrogenation process, the supported inexpensive transition metal catalysts (e.g., Ni, Mo, Co, Fe, etc.) show the unique advantages. Lercher and co-workers had reported that the conversion of crude microalgae oils into diesel-range alkanes over ZrO2 promoted Ni catalysts. They proved that the Ni/ZrO2 catalyst was efficient in deoxygenation of palmitic acid to form alkanes [10,14]. However, the deoxygenation of palmitic acid is in form of decarboxylation (CO2) and decarbonylation (CO). The carbon chain of the obtained alkanes is less than the feedstock, thus, this process is not in accordance to the concept of “green chemistry”. Onyestyák [15] studied the catalytic hydroconversion of octanoic acid over the Ni, Mo/γ-Al2O3 catalysts, obtaining an optimum acid conversion of 70% with a yield of 30% for C8 alkane, but this result was not good enough. Moreover, the results revealed that the existing of Mo is beneficial to the conversion of fatty acid into hydrocarbons with the same carbon chain compared with feedstocks. Therefore, the introduction of Mo into Ni/ZrO2 catalyst may express high catalytic performance in the deoxygenation of fatty acid. In this paper, Mo doped Ni–ZrO2 catalyst was prepared, aiming at investigating a new catalyst capable of exhibiting high efficiency for octanoic acid conversion via HDO. The effect of introducing Mo into the Ni–ZrO2 channel generated in Mo/Ni–ZrO2 samples was proved by nitrogen sorption, XRD, TPR, and TPD. This work will develop a foundation to industrial production of liquid hydrocarbon via octanoic acid HDO process over inexpensive transition metal catalysts with the economic value and strategic significance. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The Ni–ZrO2 catalyst (the Ni loading refered to 5wt%) was prepared by incipient wetness impregnation of the ZrO2 support with an appropriate amount of aqueous Ni(NO3)2·6H2O solution. After impregnation for overnight, the catalyst was dried at 100°C for 12h, then calcined at 550°C for 4h (at a heating rate of 10°Cmin−1), followed by reduction at 450°C for 3h in a constant flow of H2 (40mLmin−1). Impregnated Ni–ZrO2 with an appropriate amount of (NH4)6MoO24·4H2O aqueous solution, was then dried–calcined–reduced at the same condition as the Ni–ZrO2, afterwards obtained the Mo promoter nickel-based catalyst defined as xMo/Ni–ZrO2 in which the Mo, Ni loadings were x wt% (x =0, 5, 10, 15) and 5wt%, respectively. 2.2 Catalyst characterization N2-adsorption isotherms were measured on a Micromeritics ASAP2010 instrument at −196°C. In a typical run, firstly, the samples were degassed at 300°C for 3h. The surface areas were calculated by the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method. Transmission electron microscope (TEM) was carried out on a FEI tecnai F20 instrument. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (λ =0.1541nm, 36kV, 20mA, scanning step=2°min−1). Data were recorded in the 2θ range 5–80°. TPR was conducted with a TP-5076 multiple adsorption instrument (Xian-quan, China). It was performed at a rate of 5°Cmin−1 from room temperature up to 800°C in a flow of 5% H2/N2. The consumption of H2 was analyzed online with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) measurements were carried out to determine the amount and relative strength of acid sites. Typically 0.2g of a sample was employed. The sample was pretreated at 500°C in a flow of He (30mLmin−1) for 1h and adsorbed a flow of NH3 (15mLmin−1) at100°C for 30min, and then purged with He until the physically adsorbed NH3 was removed. The sample was then heated under a flow of He (30mLmin−1) from 100 to 800°C with a ramp of 5°Cmin−1. The signals of NH3-TPD were recorded with an online thermal conducted detector (TCD). H2-TPD measurements were carried out by the same method of NH3-TPD, and the samples were heated from 50 to 800°C. 2.3 Catalytic activity measurements The catalytic reaction studies were performed in in a stainless autoclave with 250mL capacity. The autoclave was heated with an external electrical furnace, and the temperature was measured with a thermocouple and controlled to ±1°C. In a typical experiment, the catalyst (0.5g) and octanoic acid (1g) solution in decane (100mL) were added in the reactor. The reactor was purged three times with H2 and was then pressurized with H2 to 3MPa at ambient temperature with constant stir rate (500rpm). Then sealed and heated up to the desired reaction temperature (320°C), and the reaction time was 420min. When the reaction ended, the autoclave was cooled down to room temperature. The reaction product were analyzed on gas chromatograph (Agilent GC6820) using a GsBP-Inowax (30m×0.32mm×0.25μm) capillary column with FID. A volume of 1μL was injected for each sample, and the inlet, detect temperature and split ratio were 280°C, 280°C, and 10:1, respectively. The column temperature was programmed as follows: started at 50°C for 2min, and then ramped to 220°C at a rate of 10°Cmin−1, holding for 5min. Conversion was defined as mol% and calculated as moles of converted octanoic acid per mole of starting octanoic acid times 100%. Yields were defined as mol% and were calculated as moles of each product per mole of starting octanoic acid times 100%. Selectivity was calculated as dividing yield by conversion times 100%. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalysts characterization The Ni–ZrO2 and xMo/Ni–ZrO2 catalysts were well characterized via different methods. The surface area of various catalysts was listed in Table 1 . As it can be seen, the surface area increased with Mo content. Although the surface areas in the present work were smaller than that in Peng et al.’s work [10], the Ni–ZrO2 and xMo/Ni–ZrO2 catalysts performed superior catalytic activity in octanoic conversion and this would be discussed in details below. Fig. 1 (a) showed that the Ni was homogeneously supported on the surface of ZrO2 particles. When introducing Mo to the Ni–ZrO2 catalyst, there appeared a phase boundary of MoO3 and ZrO2 support; till the Mo content increased to 15wt%, the phase boundary disappeared, which demonstrated that the ZrO2 support as well as Ni components were completely covered by MoO3. 3.1.1 X-ray diffraction analysis The XRD patterns of the Ni–ZrO2 and 10Mo/Ni–ZrO2 were shown in Fig. 2 . It was shown that the diffraction peaks of Ni–ZrO2 were at 2θ =30.6°, 35.3°, 50.9°, and 60.5°, which were assigned to the diffraction peaks of cubic ZrO2, defined as c-ZrO2. No other crystalline phases were detected in the Ni–ZrO2 sample, it was concluded that the Ni0 have uniformly dispersed in the ZrO2 support. When Mo was introduce into the Ni-ZrO2 channel, the ZrO2 support crystal transformed from c-ZrO2 to monoclinic form (the characteristic diffraction peaks at 2θ =17.3°, 24°, 28.2°, 31.4°, 34°, and 50.2° which is defined as m-ZrO2). It owed to a small amount of Mo6+ ions incorporated into the ZrO2 lattices [16]. Rhodes and Bell [17] obtained that there existed a high concentration of anionic vacancies on the surface of m-ZrO2. Such vacancies expose Zr4+ cations, which act as Lewis acid centers and enhance the Brønsted acidity of adjacent ZrOH groups. The presence of Zr4+ sites and adjacent Brønsted acidic ZrOH groups contributes to the adsorption of RCOOH as RCOOZr groups, and subsequently facilitate the carboxylic acid groups hydrogenate to alkanes over the Ni sites. Though no signs of crystalline MoO3 formation could be found in the XRD pattern of 10Mo/Ni–ZrO2, which was evidenced from the absence of MoO3 with main characteristic peaks at 12.8°, 23.3°, 25.7°, and 27.3° [18], the MoO3 did exist in the catalysts which could be made out from the detection of reduction peaks of MoO3 in the H2-TPR patterns of Fig. 3 , which illustrates that the MoO3 have uniformly dispersed in the ZrO2 support. 3.1.2 H2-TPR analysis Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) was performed on the calcined catalyst precursors (Fig. 3). There were two reduction peaks in TPR pattern of Ni–ZrO2, the prominent reduction peak occurred at a lower temperature of 360°C, which was characteristic for the reduction of the surface NiO, suggesting that NiO clusters have a weak interaction with the ZrO2 support after impregnation [1]. A shoulder peak occurred at a higher temperature of 428°C, which represented the reduction peak of bulk NiO. After doping 10wt% Mo to Ni–ZrO2, the temperature of reduction peak of surface NiO changed from 360 to 482°C, which illustrated that the presence of Mo specie appears to strengthen the interaction of NiO with ZrO2 support. This helped to prevent sintering of NiO during reduction [19]. The reduction of Mo6+–Mo4+ occurred at 535°C, meanwhile, the peak of 707°C was assigned to the reduction of Mo4+–Mo0 [20]. For 10Mo/Ni–ZrO2, no reduction peak of bulk NiO was observed, which was owing to its overlaps with the reduction peak of Mo6+–Mo4+. Since the catalysts used for experiments were reduced at 450°C, the active components of the catalysts should be Ni0 and MoO3. Besides that, the detection of reduction peaks of NiO and MoO3 further confirmed the analysis result of XRD that the Ni0 and MoO3 species did exist and uniformly dispersed in the ZrO2 support. 3.1.3 NH3-TPD analysis The profiles of NH3-TPD to characterize acidic properties of Ni–ZrO2 and 10Mo/Ni–ZrO2 were shown in Fig. 4 . Generally, the acid sites could be divided into weak acid sites (150–250°C), medium acid sites (250–400°C), and strong acid sites (>400°C) according to desorption temperature. From Fig. 4, three distinct peaks were observed in both the catalysts, among which one correspond to medium acid sites and the other represented strong acid sites. The NH3 desorption temperature of medium acid sites over 10Mo/Ni–ZrO2 was higher than that of Ni–ZrO2. This suggested that the strength of medium acidic sites over 10Mo/Ni–ZrO2 was stronger than that of Ni–ZrO2. In addition, 10Mo/Ni–ZrO2 had more amount of strong acid sites compared to Ni–ZrO2. To conclude, the acidic property of the Ni–ZrO2 catalyst was greatly pronounced after doping with Mo. 3.1.4 H2-TPD analysis H2-TPD experiments have been performed over the Ni–ZrO2 and 10Mo/Ni–ZrO2 catalysts in order to obtain information on the surface structure as well as to determine the amount of chemisorbed hydrogen. As it shown in Fig. 5 , the profiles in general showed one domain of H2 desorption peaks in a low-temperature region below 600°C (with maxima at 300–330°C) and one peak in a high-temperature region with maxima at 670°C. The lower temperature peak was generally attributed to H2 desorbed from the surface Ni particles and the shoulder peak (peak 2) which was around at 450°C could be assigned to the desorption of H2 adsorbed on surface of large Ni crystals [21,22]. Many authors have explained the high-temperature peak derived from the hydrogen spillover that takes place during high-temperature (above 500°C) treatments of the catalysts [23,24], so it was clear that the peak 3 owed to hydrogen spillover. In addition, the area of low-temperature peak for 10Mo/Ni–ZrO2 was much larger than that of Ni–ZrO2, which demonstrated that the doping Mo to Ni–ZrO2 improved the hydrogen adsorption capacity greatly. 3.2 Deoxygenation of octanoic acid over Ni-ZrO2 catalyst The catalytic performance of the Ni–ZrO2 for octanoic acid HDO as a function of time were shown in Fig. 6 . The conversion of octanoic acid was 92.79% with yields of 69.68% for heptane, 5% for octane, 5.95% for lighter alkanes, 5.75% for octanol, 3.30% for octanal, and 3% for octyl octanoate over Ni–ZrO2 catalyst at 320°C in the presence of 3MPa H2. As it shown in Fig. 6b, octanal was the major product in the first 3h, with a maximum initial yield of 5.26%, then decreased rapidly and remained at around 3%. At the same time, the yield of octanol increased gradually and reached a maximum yield of 7.49% after reaction for 300min, which then decreased to 5.75%. Octanal was in equilibrium with octanol. The yield of octyl octanoate, formed by the esterification of octanoic acid with octanol, increased to a maximum of 5.44% after reaction for 360min and then gradually decreased to 3% until the reaction was finished due to hydrogenolysis over Ni active sites. The major product – heptane (Fig. 6a) produced through octanal decarbonylation increased gradually as the reaction proceeded. Hydrocarbons with fewer than 8 carbon atoms were produced either by cracking over acid sites or by hydrogenolysis over metallic sites of Ni–ZrO2 [25]. The yield of lighter hydrocarbons increased continuously, but remained below 6% at complete conversion. There were also a few amount of octane be detected through the reaction process, which resulted from octanol dehydration–hydrogenation reactions. Thus, the dehydration product-octene was not detected; it might due to its low yielding and fast hydrogenation of the double bond. 3.3 The effect of doping Mo to Ni–ZrO2 on deoxygenation of octanoic acid 3.3.1 The influence of Mo content It is shown that the introduction of Mo is beneficial to the conversion of octanic acid into C8 alkane distinctly. In order to investigate the effect of Mo species, xMo/Ni–ZrO2 catalysts with the different distribution of Mo species and constant distribution of Ni species were prepared. As was shown in Fig. 7 , adding certain Mo particles to the Ni–ZrO2 catalyst could not only improve the octanoic acid conversion but also greatly change the distribution of products. When no Mo content, the major product of octanoic acid HDO was heptane; once doping 1wt% Mo to Ni–ZrO2, the selectivity of heptane decreased from 75.10% to 26.77%, meanwhile, the selectivity of octane sharply increased from 5.39 to 66.12%. We could also observe that the octane selectivity had an increasing trend with the Mo content increasing until the Mo content reached to 10wt%, at which the octane selectivity reached to its maximum of 77.07%. When the Mo content increased to 15wt%, the octanoic acid conversion as well as octane selectivity sharply decreased. This could be attributed to that an excess of Mo particles would cover the Ni active sites as well as anionic vacancies on the surface of ZrO2 support which could be verified from the TEM images in Fig. 1; in addition, sintering might be caused when Mo particles were loaded too much, and this would be discussed in Section 3.4 below. Since the 10Mo/Ni–ZrO2 catalyst had the optimum product distributions, we applied it to explore the next experiments. As shown in Table 1, the surface area of 10Mo/Ni–ZrO2 catalyst has doubled compared to the Ni–ZrO2, it could be concluded that the addition of Mo particles led to increase in the surface area, which in turn contributes to the catalytic activity of the catalyst. In addition, the H2-TPD profiles in Fig. 5 has proved that introducing 10wt% Mo to Ni–ZrO2 induced greatly improving the hydrogen adsorption capacity, which in turn facilitates octanol dehydration–hydrogenation reactions, which ultimately facilities the formation of octane. The detection of octene also confirmed the existence of dehydration–hydrogenation reactions of octanol. Since the different product distributions suggested different HDO mechanisms prevailed over the Ni–ZrO2 and Mo/Ni–ZrO2 catalysts. For the Ni–ZrO2 catalyst, on account of the fact that octanal was the initial product of octanoic acid hydrogenation, the main reaction was octanoic acid hydrogenation to octanal then decarbonylation to produce heptane; meanwhile, when Mo/Ni–ZrO2, hydrogenation of octanal–octanol followed by dehydration–hydrogenation to octane was the major routine. 3.3.2 The effect of reaction temperatures and H2 pressures on octanoic acid HDO In order to substantiate a possible mechanism for the octanoic acid HDO reaction, we studied the influence of the temperatures and H2 partial pressures on the activity of the Ni–ZrO2 and 10Mo/Ni–ZrO2 catalysts. The octanoic acid conversion and detailed product distributions for the two catalysts as a function of reaction temperature are compared in Table 2 . For Ni–ZrO2, an increase of temperature from 300 to 320°C at 3MPa H2 enhanced the octanoic acid conversion from 60.03 to 92.79%, keeping increasing the temperature to 350°C, comparable acid conversion and distinct product distributions were obtained. Such as, the selectivity of lighter alkanes enhanced from 6.46 to 14.55%, meanwhile, octane increased from 5.81 to 17.5% with the detection of octene and the decrease of reaction intermediates of octanal, octanol, and octyl octanoate. Higher temperature was beneficial to the generation of C8 and lighter alkanes, which attributed to that dehydrogenation and cracking prevailed at high temperatures. After doping 10wt% Mo to N–ZrO2, the octanoic acid conversion enhanced to 91.37% and 100% when the reaction temperature were 300°C and 320°C, respectively, indicating that the 10Mo/Ni–ZrO2 catalyst had a higher catalytic activity than that of Ni–ZrO2. Fig. 8 shows two distinct trends of octanoic acid conversion and product distributions over Ni–ZrO2 and 10Mo/Ni–ZrO2 catalysts as the function of H2 partial pressure. Over Ni–ZrO2, the octanoic acid conversion and the yields of C7, C8, and lighter alkanes were found to increase and reached a maximum, while the reaction intermediates of octanol and octyl octanoate arrived to a minimum when the H2 partial pressure increased to 3MPa (Fig. 8a and a′); once the H2 partial pressure exceed 3MPa, an opposite tendency was showing itself. It is well known that a certain amount of H2 can inhibit the carbon deposition on the surface of a catalyst which favors the catalyst’s reaction activity; however, too much volume of H2 would compete for the adsorption sites with the the octanoic acid, so there appeared a decreased tendency for the octanoic acid conversion when the H2 partial pressure exceed 3MPa. Fig. 8b and b′ demonstrates that the octanoic acid conversion and the main product – C8 increased distinctly with the increasing of H2 partial pressure. Meanwhile, the concentration of C8 =, octanol and octyl octanoate were lower at a higher H2 partial pressure. This due to that higher H2 partial pressure favors CC bond hydrogenation and ester hydrogenolysis. The differences of the trends as a function of H2 partial pressure between the two catalysts demonstrated that the 10Mo/Ni–ZrO2 catalyst has an outstanding H2 adsorption capacity. 3.4 Reaction mechanism To develop a foundation to industrial production of liquid hydrocarbon via HDO process over inexpensive transition metal catalysts with the economic value and strategic significance, the reaction mechanism of octanoic acid over Ni–ZrO2 and 10Mo/Ni–ZrO2 was proposed. As shown above, the Ni–ZrO2 and 10Mo/Ni–ZrO2 catalysts showed different activities and selectivities under identical reaction conditions, for the Ni–ZrO2 catalyst generates mainly C7 alkane, when over 10Mo/Ni–ZrO2 C8 was the major product. Thus, there is supposed to be a different reaction pathway for octanoic acid conversion over the two catalysts (Scheme 1 ). The process involves initial absorption of octanoic acid to generate carboxylate group on the surface of ZrO2 support, then the carboxylate group hydrogenates to produce octanal over Ni sites. The octanal subsequently decarbonylates to heptane and hydrogenates to octanol simultaneously. For the 15Mo/Ni–ZrO2 catalyst, plenty of octanal was generated due to the coverage of Ni sites which led to the suppression of octanal decarbonylation or hydrogenation. Through dehydration and hydrogenation reactions, the intermediate octanol transfers to octane. In parallel, the equirium amount of the octanol also forms octyl octanoate by esterification with octanoic acid, a process that is catalyzed by the acid sites of ZrO2 support [10]. As the reaction proceeds, this ester can also be cleaved by Ni catalyzed hydrogenolysis, leading to octanol. Hence, the massive increase of the octyl octanoate when 15Mo/Ni–ZrO2 catalyst resulted from the absence of Ni sites. The acidic sites of ZrO2 support could also cause slight cracking of the straight-chain alkanes. It seems that when octanoic acid HDO over Ni–ZrO2, the reaction of octanoic acid hydrogenation to octanal then decarbonylated to heptane was the main routine; as for 10Mo/Ni–ZrO2, the higher amount of adsorption hydrogeon and stronger acid property favored hydrogenation of octanal and the dehydration–hydrogenation reactions of octanol which produces the C8 alkane as the major product. 4 Conclusion In this paper, Mo was introduced into Ni–ZrO2 catalyst, and used for the catalytic conversion of octanoic acid, which was selected as the model component of biomass derived bio-oil. The experimental results showed that the reaction product was mainly C8 alkane with a yield of 77.07% when 10Mo/Ni–ZrO2 was used as the catalyst compared with the major product of C7 alkane over Ni–ZrO2 catalyst with a yield of 69.68%. Compared to Ni–ZrO2, the HDO reaction of octanoic acid over Mo doped Ni–ZrO2 was more atomic economic, and Mo was beneficial to the conversion of fatty acid into hydrocarbons with the same carbon chain compared with feedstock. In addition, the introduction of Mo to the Ni–ZrO2 catalyst resulted in the transformation of ZrO2 support from cubic form (c-ZrO2) to monoclinic form (m-ZrO2) and the improvement of the hydrogen adsorption capacity and acid property of the catalyst. Thus, the doping of Mo favored the dehydration–hydrogenation reactions of octanol intermediate which in turn facilitated octanoic acid HDO to C8 alkane. coredata.dc:description: In the current paper, Mo doped Ni–ZrO2 catalyst was prepared, which was used for the liquid hydrocarbon from conversion of octanoic acid via hydrodeoxygenation (HDO). The experimental results showed that the reaction product is mainly C8 alkane with a yield of 77.07% when 10Mo/Ni–ZrO2 was used as the catalyst compared with the major product of C7 alkane over Ni–ZrO2 catalyst with a yield of 69.68%. The introduction of Mo into the Ni–ZrO2 channel generated in Mo/Ni–ZrO2 samples was characterized by nitrogen sorption, TEM, XRD, TPR, and TPD. The results demonstrated that the doping Mo particles to the Ni–ZrO2 catalyst resulted in the transformation of ZrO2 support from cubic form (c-ZrO2) to monoclinic form (m-ZrO2), and the improvement of the hydrogen adsorption capacity and acid property of the catalyst. Thus, the doping of Mo favored the dehydration–hydrogenation reactions of octanol intermediate which in turn facilitated octanoic acid HDO to C8 alkane. Therefore, a novel approach to octanoic acid HDO to C8 alkane is introduced, which provides a basis as well as technical parameters for its further industrialization.
coredata.dc:title: Towards conversion of octanoic acid to liquid hydrocarbon via hydrodeoxygenation over Mo promoter nickel-based catalyst
